title: Habit Tracker — a tiny, offline-first Ionic/Angular app with smart reminders
content: A personal project to learn Angular the practical way: I built a Habit Tracker with a clean dark UI, offline storage, and on-device notifications. Below I walk through what the app does, a few design decisions, and the little engineering bits that made it stable on Android (Capacitor) without needing any backend.
description: ### Core features (what you can do)
- **Create habits** with a name, **period** (Day / Week / Month) and **repetitions per period**.
- **Add reminders** directly when creating a habit or later in Settings: pick a time and select weekdays (defaults to all days if you don’t choose).
- **Edit reminders** at any time; the app cancels old schedules and creates new ones to avoid duplicates.
- **Track progress**: see *current* and *longest streaks* plus a compact streak timeline for each habit.
- **Stay private**: everything is stored locally on your device; there’s no login and no data leaves your phone.
### Screens at a glance
- **Habits list** *(first screenshot)* — compact cards show your progress and streak counters. The floating **+** opens the add dialog.
- **New habit** *(second screenshot)* — choose period & repetitions; tap **Add notification** to attach reminders before saving.
- **Add reminder modal** *(third screenshot)* — a simple time wheel and weekday chips (Mo–Su). If you don’t select days, the reminder runs every day.
- **Settings** *(fourth screenshot)* — per-habit details: current/longest streaks, timeline, quick actions (manage reminders, reset period, delete).
### Tech stack
- **Ionic + Angular (standalone components)** for the UI and routing.
- **Capacitor** for native bridges, especially **Local Notifications** on Android.
- **Offline-first storage** via Capacitor Preferences/Storage; no server required.
- **Dark theme** by default; high-contrast accents for category colors.
### Notifications: what matters on Android 13+
- Android 13+ requires a **runtime permission** for posting notifications. The app asks **only when you add/save reminders**, not on the first launch.
- To keep the app stable, all plugin calls are wrapped in `try/catch`, and scheduling only runs **after** permission is granted.
- Reminders are scheduled per habit and weekday. When you edit reminders, the app **cancels** the old ones first, then **reschedules** the new set.
### Little engineering details
- **Crash-proof plugin usage**: permission checks & scheduling are isolated in a `NotificationService` so UI code stays simple and safe.
- **Deterministic IDs** for reminders (per habit, per time, per day) prevent duplicates.
- **Default-sane UX**: if you add a reminder time but pick no weekdays, the app assumes *every day*.
- **No background surprise**: reminders exist only because you created them; the app doesn’t auto-add or reschedule behind your back.
### What I learned
- Start with a tiny vertical slice (one habit, one reminder), then harden the edges (permissions, cancel/reschedule).
- Capacitor is great for *just-enough native* without leaving the Angular mindset.
- Stability on Android is mostly about **when** you call native APIs and **what happens when they fail** — handle both deliberately.
### Roadmap
- Optional iOS build & minor UI polish for larger screens.
- Export/backup of local data.
- Gentle onboarding & tips for first-time users.
### Try it
The app is currently distributed via Google Play test tracks for quick feedback. If you’re on the tester list, use the opt-in link to install from the Play Store and you’ll get updates automatically.
